componenttext: We'll now take our next question from Joe Greff with JPMorgan.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: With respect to your 2010 outlook, if you were to look at it on a quarterly basis, I know you don’t break out but just broadly, when do you see rate recovering to exhibit some year-over-year growth. And I guess, when would you see comparable operating p
componenttext: With respect to your 2010 outlook, if you were to look at it on a quarterly basis, I know you don’t break out but just broadly, when do you see rate recovering to exhibit some year-over-year growth. And I guess, when would you see comparable operating profit margins start to show in some year-over-year increases?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that’s probably the trickiest question that we’re trying to contemplate right now. What I would say to you, as you well know, is that the recovery in rates is going to happen on a market-by-market basis. And some of the markets that Larry talked
componenttext: Well, that’s probably the trickiest question that we’re trying to contemplate right now. What I would say to you, as you well know, is that the recovery in rates is going to happen on a market-by-market basis. And some of the markets that Larry talked about, that I think we've got a chance of seeing some rate growth relatively quickly, would include some of the big East Coast markets like Boston, New York and DC. I think New Orleans surprisingly is having a pretty good year and we would expect to see some rate growth there. Miami, in part because of the burst around the Super Bowl, but I also think in general we’re seeing some strength in that market. So that’s another market where we think it's likely that we’ll see some rate growth in the relatively near term. Portfolio-wide, I would at best say it’s -- it's probably at best the second half of the year. Certainly within the realm of the guidance that we provided, we're really not anticipating that it happens until the end of the year. And I think it's a little touch-and-go on whether or not we actually get the true rate growth for a full quarter by the end of the year. Probably at the high-end of our guidance, there's a shot at that. On the margin front, I think you -- our estimate is that we are looking at a 50 basis point decline tied to a 4% overall full year RevPAR growth rate. Again, my guess is that the margin and the -- because margin growth is going to be tied to both overall level of RevPAR increase as well as, to some degree, whether that is happening because of rate or because of occupancy, if there's an opportunity for positive margins it’s certainly near the end of the year.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: If you were to adjust your first quarter for reporting outside of, I guess NAREIT reporting system, what would have been a quarterized EBITDA number for your entire portfolio?
componenttext: If you were to adjust your first quarter for reporting outside of, I guess NAREIT reporting system, what would have been a quarterized EBITDA number for your entire portfolio?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: From the standpoint of EBITDA, we haven't calculated that number.
componenttext: From the standpoint of EBITDA, we haven't calculated that number.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll now move on to Chris Woronka with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll now move on to Chris Woronka with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Ed, if I look at the guidance for the full year now, at the high-end of the range, stripping out the effect of the cancel attrition fees, 4% RevPAR would kind of be flattish to margins, maybe plus 20. Does that imply that you kind of need 4% RevPAR growth
componenttext: Ed, if I look at the guidance for the full year now, at the high-end of the range, stripping out the effect of the cancel attrition fees, 4% RevPAR would kind of be flattish to margins, maybe plus 20. Does that imply that you kind of need 4% RevPAR growth going forward to get those flat margins?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's a correct assumption as it relates to this year. Going forward, ultimately margin growth ties to the relationship between revenue growth, which is of course more than just RevPAR growth, and inflation. So if we continue to see inflation stay
componenttext: I think it's a correct assumption as it relates to this year. Going forward, ultimately margin growth ties to the relationship between revenue growth, which is of course more than just RevPAR growth, and inflation. So if we continue to see inflation stay at a fairly low level, plus or minus 2%, then I would expect that we would be able to see margin growth in '11 and '12 at below 4% RevPAR level. Now I suspect that if the recovery continues, that won't be a problem because we're going to be seeing stronger levels of RevPAR increase than that. But I think you could see margin growth at less than 4%.  As we've commented in the past, the transition here when one goes from having been in free fall to starting to see RevPAR recovery and business recovery is always a tricky year for margins, while I would say there was tremendous strides made at all of our properties at taking out cost. There clearly are some costs that came out of our operations that are not sustainable, and so typically in that first eight to 12 months of RevPAR recovery, some of those costs trickle back in, which usually leads to the first year of positive RevPAR growth having less than impressive margins. But normally, especially if we’re doing our job on the asset management side, once you get past that initial kind of recovery of some expenses,you get back into a more traditional relationship. And as long as RevPAR and revenue growth are outpacing inflation, we should see margin growth.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you remind us what maybe the incremental -- you said for the first quarter $12 million incremental cancel attrition fees, can you kind of tell us what it was for full year '09, maybe relative to, I don’t know, ’07 or…
componenttext: Can you remind us what maybe the incremental -- you said for the first quarter $12 million incremental cancel attrition fees, can you kind of tell us what it was for full year '09, maybe relative to, I don’t know, ’07 or…

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: It's $40 million incremental, over a typical year.
componenttext: It's $40 million incremental, over a typical year.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. One final one on the asset front. You guys have sold some non-core stuff, and I don't think anybody looks too hard at the prices per key or anything on that, but with all this capital that appears to be available, do you think about selling w
componenttext: Okay, great. One final one on the asset front. You guys have sold some non-core stuff, and I don't think anybody looks too hard at the prices per key or anything on that, but with all this capital that appears to be available, do you think about selling what might not be a non-core asset but, maybe not a trophy asset, but something where you get a pretty substantial price per key just to kind of demonstrate the value that I know you guys think is even in the portfolio?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Chris, I don't know that there would be -- I wouldn't do it necessarily to demonstrate value, I think, but you raised a good point. Pricing has certainly recovered more quickly than some folks had anticipated, and as operations begin to improve, one can g
componenttext: Chris, I don't know that there would be -- I wouldn't do it necessarily to demonstrate value, I think, but you raised a good point. Pricing has certainly recovered more quickly than some folks had anticipated, and as operations begin to improve, one can get more comfortable with selling some of the assets that we don't expect to be owning in 2014 or 2015 a bit sooner. We are in the process right now of evaluating the portfolio and looking at a number of assets to determine if it is better to sell those assets now and take advantage of a fair amount of capital that's not able to be deployed, or whether we’re able to – whether we would be better off waiting for the NOI to recover a bit more and then put those properties on the market. That's one of the reasons why we made the statement that, while we're not putting any more sales – or not contemplating specific sales in the context of our guidance, we are intending to market a few properties and we'll sort of see how that plays out. But what I would say on that is because of the amount of capital we have, we do not need to effect a sale for liquidity reasons. So we will be very, very price sensitive in any of those marketing opportunities. If we're not hitting the number that we want, we will not be a seller because the only reason to do it is the one that you’ve outlined, to take advantage of a strong market and sell some assets that, while they are non-core for us, could clearly be a good acquisition for somebody else.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll now move onto Jeffrey Donnelly with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: We'll now move onto Jeffrey Donnelly with Wells Fargo.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: A few questions, actually, on your 2010 RevPAR outlook. Are you able to break out for us the composition of your outlook between occupancy rate and,I guess I would call it mix shift?
componenttext: A few questions, actually, on your 2010 RevPAR outlook. Are you able to break out for us the composition of your outlook between occupancy rate and,I guess I would call it mix shift?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Not as precisely as you would probably like, Jeff. I think that’s the tricky part when you're in this sort of a transition. As we clearly saw tremendous occupancy growth in the first quarter and that was unfortunately offset by rate declines, we work ou
componenttext: Not as precisely as you would probably like, Jeff. I think that’s the tricky part when you're in this sort of a transition. As we clearly saw tremendous occupancy growth in the first quarter and that was unfortunately offset by rate declines, we work our way through the quarter, though we’ve probably been expecting to see the occupancy run at a fairly heavy rate but the question is going to be how quickly can we eliminate negative rate and move into positive rate. Let me give you a couple of other insights around why we got more optimistic relative to RevPAR for the rest of the year. The big drive for us was what was happening on the transient side. As I mentioned, we were up 12% in overall transient demand. We are practically, for the first quarter at least, back to where we were in 2007. But the biggest key for us was the fact that when you combine corporate and special corporate business, we were up 15% in room nights. Now, while we were still down in rate in those segments, the fact that, that demand was coming back was pretty key for us because we had not really seen that happen even in the fourth quarter of last year. And hence when that start to occur, that's a great sign for the fact that the business is going to rebuild. And I think the other piece of it is, that as you look at what was happening on the group side, we started out the quarter at the deficit for both the full year and for the quarter. We very quickly closed that deficit in the first quarter and ended up positive in room nights. A lot of that was because on the association events people showed up, and in fact we started to run into situations where more people showed up than we had rooms available. And even on the corporate side, we started to find that our booking pace was accelerating beyond what we had expected. So as we look at the activity for the second and third quarter, it’s very solid. There is still a little bit of weakness in the fourth quarter but we are up for the full year in terms of group booking pace now, which we haven't been able to say for quite some time. And I think we felt that because that's such an important component of our business and because when you go back and look at where we were compared to '07, we had really lost the most in terms of group room nights compared to the other segments in our business, the fact that, that was beginning to recover, led us to look much more optimistically at the rest of the year.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Sticking with RevPAR, I’m curious, and the Marriott obviously had a pretty robust outlook for the U.S., and I mean the market expects Starwood, if history proves true, to ratchet their outlook above Marriott, since both of those brands comprise the majo
componenttext: Sticking with RevPAR, I’m curious, and the Marriott obviously had a pretty robust outlook for the U.S., and I mean the market expects Starwood, if history proves true, to ratchet their outlook above Marriott, since both of those brands comprise the majority of your earnings, and you arguably own the best hotels on average within their portfolios, why is it that your 2010 RevPAR outlook of 1% to 4%, is where it’s at? Because typically, your guidance is much tighter in line with someone like Marriott International. Is it -- I guess I'll call it  conservatism for the sake of conservatism, or do you think that their expectations for the back half of the year are a little more aggressive?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: My guess is it’s a combination of us being a little bit more conservative and of course recognizing that ultimately it's not just RevPAR,  it's EBITDA for us. Whereas for them, they're much more sensitive just to the top line changes because the managem
componenttext: My guess is it’s a combination of us being a little bit more conservative and of course recognizing that ultimately it's not just RevPAR,  it's EBITDA for us. Whereas for them, they're much more sensitive just to the top line changes because the management fees don’t represent anywhere near as big a component in their earnings as EBITDA does for us.  At the end of the day, I think I'd reiterate what I said the last quarter when there was a little bit of a gap between where we were and where both of them were, which is that there's really no reason, given that I would agree with your point that we own some of their best hotels and we typically perform pretty much in line with them, there's no reason in our mind why we would underperform either of them. I think it’s just, obviously we are moving our expectations a fair amount from one quarter to the next and I think we'd rather -- we don't want to necessarily get ahead of ourselves. You should take from our call, we feel very good about what we are seeing in the first quarter. But we are still in a recovering economy and we want to take note of that.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: One last question. We've heard some anecdotes that group hotels might be benefiting from recovering attendance, effectively that group sizes being larger than the room block that was booked,say back in 2008 and '09 before this year, and then providing hot
componenttext: One last question. We've heard some anecdotes that group hotels might be benefiting from recovering attendance, effectively that group sizes being larger than the room block that was booked,say back in 2008 and '09 before this year, and then providing hotels, group hotels such as yours, with an upside to group rates at the margin from that overflow business. Is there any truth to that reality or that rumor? Are you guys seeing that so far this year?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: On an anecdotal basis, we've certainly had situations where more people showed up than we had expected. I think what we are finding though is that the hotels are constantly in touch with the bigger groups to understand what their room nights are going to
componenttext: On an anecdotal basis, we've certainly had situations where more people showed up than we had expected. I think what we are finding though is that the hotels are constantly in touch with the bigger groups to understand what their room nights are going to ultimately come out to be. And what they have been finding is that where a lot of times last year, we might have expected 800 rooms and by the time we got two weeks out we were starting to find that 800 was turning into 700 or 750. What we are hearing from our GMs at this point is that holding at 800, it may be coming in higher than that in some cases. The key for us on that is to really understand that and start to build that into our revenue expectations. Because as we begin to get more confident that those associations will not only fulfill their full block but actually begin to exceed it, that allows us to begin to do some nickshift by cutting off some of the cheaper channels that we might have available, and save rooms either for that higher-priced group or simply make certain we save enough rooms in certain markets where we’re only selling rooms to that higher-priced corporate customer as opposed to that lower-priced discount customer.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll now move on to Ryan Meliker with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll now move on to Ryan Meliker with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, in terms of the RevPAR front and where things are looking right now. Can you give us any additional detail on how much your group booking base moved up for the quarter in first quarter, and how it moved from the last time we spoke to today f
componenttext: First of all, in terms of the RevPAR front and where things are looking right now. Can you give us any additional detail on how much your group booking base moved up for the quarter in first quarter, and how it moved from the last time we spoke to today for the full year,and both in terms of rooms and rate?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We gave some data before. Let me try to approach it in a slightly different way. If you look at what was happening on net booking pace for the first quarter, we generally found that in the first quarter itself our net bookings were up by over 100% compare
componenttext: We gave some data before. Let me try to approach it in a slightly different way. If you look at what was happening on net booking pace for the first quarter, we generally found that in the first quarter itself our net bookings were up by over 100% compared to where we were in '09. And those bookings actually exceeded the pace that we had in 2007 which we tend to use as sort as a stabilized year by more than 25%. If you look at how it played out for the quarter, we started off down about 6% and ended up slightly. So you can see that the fact that we booked so many more rooms in the quarter than we traditionally have done, allowed us to close the gap in a way that we probably wouldn't have in the past.  On a full-year basis, you're finding that more -- the bookings are short-term, there still is not -- we haven't hit that magic moment that I can tell yet where somebody calls up, wants to do an event in four weeks and finds out that there's no room available at the inn.  So we haven't quite gotten to that point because of where our occupancy levels were. So you're finding that most of the success in the booking pace side is relatively short-term which is why our second quarter bookings are up almost over 250% compared to 2009. Now recognized there weren't a lot of short-term bookings happening at this time last year, but the reality is even the second quarter bookings when you go back and compare them to 2007 are slightly positive. So we would take that as a good sign, too. The net of it is that when we started off the year being negative in terms of overall room nights, we've closed that gap in a material way and in fact now even with adjusting those umber of nights booked to reflect what we thought was a cancellation that happened last year, because I think that gives you a cleaner sense of the data, instead of being down 6% we are now up 3% to 4%. So I think that obviously is a pretty good change in a relatively short period of time.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: How do rates look, looking at today versus the rest of the year, compared to last year?
componenttext: How do rates look, looking at today versus the rest of the year, compared to last year?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think you should still assume that rates are -- probably the short-term rates that we’re booking at are generally lower than the rates that are on the books, but there are some markets where that’s beginning to turn.
componenttext: I think you should still assume that rates are -- probably the short-term rates that we’re booking at are generally lower than the rates that are on the books, but there are some markets where that’s beginning to turn.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Alright. And can you clarify to what degree lower, are we talking 0% to 5%, or 5% to 10%, if better?
componenttext: Alright. And can you clarify to what degree lower, are we talking 0% to 5%, or 5% to 10%, if better?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yeah, not in a way that I think would be meaningful.
componenttext: Yeah, not in a way that I think would be meaningful.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: As you guys are obviously looking at dispositions and looking at acquisitions, what is your general sense in terms of the way you’re approaching valuations for potential acquisitions and dispositions, and the way some of the competitors are going up aga
componenttext: As you guys are obviously looking at dispositions and looking at acquisitions, what is your general sense in terms of the way you’re approaching valuations for potential acquisitions and dispositions, and the way some of the competitors are going up against for bidding on these properties you’re looking at. It seems like cap rates right now are at historically low levels which makes sense given the historically low net income. But I feel like most people aren't looking at valuation on cap rates. Are you focusing on value relative to replacements costs or a price per key? How are you guys generating your numbers and how do you think your competitors are?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: The way we are looking at acquisitions fits within the model that we always expressed in terms of how we look at transactions. What we look at, we start with trying to understand what we think based on our projections is an unlevered rate of return from a
componenttext: The way we are looking at acquisitions fits within the model that we always expressed in terms of how we look at transactions. What we look at, we start with trying to understand what we think based on our projections is an unlevered rate of return from a particular asset. So in each instance what we're going to do with that is we’re going to make certain assumptions about what the performance is going to be this year and then we're going to assess what we think is likely to happen for that particular asset and that particular market. Over the next few years, and I think having kind of calculated in what we think the recovery is, we would probably stabilize it a longer term revenue and EBITDA or NOI growth rate and carry that out to ultimately get to a 10-year discounted cash flow. If you think about how that works, obviously markets that have fallen further but then are expected to rise faster are going to ultimately end up with lower cap rates today, but that's just reflecting the particular circumstances and their market. The other major element that we would look at is the one that you were referencing which is trying to understand where you are in a discount to replacement cost. I think one of the key factors in employing that in your analysis, is that to the extent that you are legitimately analyzing what your replacement cost is, if you're buying at a meaningful discount to replacement cost, well that in and of itself does not tell you that you're necessarily going to have a successful investment. It does give you a sense that it is harder on a relative basis if the discount is larger or a new competitor had come into your market simply because the cost to build that new competitor are probably not going to make sense in the context of the return on the investment until cash flow depreciated meaningfully. So discount to replacement costs becomes a good gut check for us on whether or not -- if you are underwriting a very aggressive recovery for an asset that you thought was at replacement cost, you probably have to ask yourself if you're really being fair about the likelihood of new supply in that market. So those would be the two primary things that we would look at. My guess is at the end of the day, I think most of our competitors are pretty sophisticated. They would each have their own take, but I suspect that they're looking at it in generally the same way.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll now move on to the Joshua Attie with Citigroup.
componenttext: We'll now move on to the Joshua Attie with Citigroup.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I just have a quick question on the margins. When I look at the high-end of your guidance of up 4 and margins down 50, and then I strip out the impact of the cancellation fees for the full year, I get kind of 5% to 6% RevPAR growth, 2Q to 4Q, and call it
componenttext: I just have a quick question on the margins. When I look at the high-end of your guidance of up 4 and margins down 50, and then I strip out the impact of the cancellation fees for the full year, I get kind of 5% to 6% RevPAR growth, 2Q to 4Q, and call it 75 basis points of margin, adjusted for the cancellation fees. Two questions: One, am I thinking about that the right way; and two, what do you think those margins would be in year two of the recovery on similar RevPAR kind of adjusting for the fact that you have some cost added back this year?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Josh, it might make sense with respect to the assumptions that are you coming up with the second half of this year, I suspect that it may make sense for you to catch up with Greg to go over that a bit, because it's a little hard to capture that on-the-fly
componenttext: Josh, it might make sense with respect to the assumptions that are you coming up with the second half of this year, I suspect that it may make sense for you to catch up with Greg to go over that a bit, because it's a little hard to capture that on-the-fly. What I would say with respect to the next year is,if we're thinking about 2011, is I think you’ve got to -- I’d go back to the comments that I made before that I think this year is tougher. The speed with which everything recovers this year will probably have played some role in looking at what happens in margins next year, and to the extent that we begin to see a stronger recovery. And so some of that cost increase that I'm expecting is going to happen, happens this year. It probably sets us up for a more normalized year in 2011 with respect to margin. When you step back and look at what would happen in 2011, if you were to have 5% RevPAR growth, I would be very disappointed if we didn't have some margin growth there. I am not anticipating that inflation is going to be particularly high next year and so assuming that, that plays out that way and that there is a reasonable gap between RevPAR/revenues and inflation, we should be in a situation where we should see some margin growth.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: As you know, Josh, even though Ed mentioned earlier in this call that rates could turn positive at some point in the second half of this year, when you’re looking at the full year results with RevPAR of 1% to 4%, most if not all of that is due to an inc
componenttext: As you know, Josh, even though Ed mentioned earlier in this call that rates could turn positive at some point in the second half of this year, when you’re looking at the full year results with RevPAR of 1% to 4%, most if not all of that is due to an increase in occupancy. So of course next year, when you have a bigger part of the RevPAR increase will be weighed, obviously that would be helpful for margin as well.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We will now take our final question from Smedes Rose with Keefe, Bruyette, & Woods.
componenttext: We will now take our final question from Smedes Rose with Keefe, Bruyette, & Woods.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Your ATM still has, looks like you could issue about 3 million or 4 million more shares on that, would you expect to exhaust that and reload, or do you kind of feel like you're done on that side of the liquidity?
componenttext: Your ATM still has, looks like you could issue about 3 million or 4 million more shares on that, would you expect to exhaust that and reload, or do you kind of feel like you're done on that side of the liquidity?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, Smedes. It all depends upon how active we can ultimately be on the acquisition side. We obviously have a fair amount of capital right now. As Larry mentioned in his comments, we got a pleasant surprise when the exchangeable that wa
componenttext: That's a good question, Smedes. It all depends upon how active we can ultimately be on the acquisition side. We obviously have a fair amount of capital right now. As Larry mentioned in his comments, we got a pleasant surprise when the exchangeable that was puttable to us a couple weeks ago wasn't put, so that gives us an extra $325 million of capital that we weren't counting on. So we’ll take that into account in deciding what to do with the continuous equity program. At the end of the day, I think folks should assume that we are trying to add additional hotels to our portfolio and that we will ultimately draw on that capital in order to help fund that growth. In the long run, I would expect that we would have another continuous equity program. We do want to have – I think that's a very cost effective way to fund the equity portion of our balance sheet, but it's all going to be tied to exactly what level of growth we’re having and because if you don't have the growth then you don't necessarily need to issue the incremental equity.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: That does end our question-and-answer session. I would now like to turn the call back over to Mr. Walter.
componenttext: That does end our question-and-answer session. I would now like to turn the call back over to Mr. Walter.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010

componenttext: Thank you very much, all, for joining us today. We appreciated the opportunity to discuss our first quarter results and our outlook. We look forward to providing you with more insight into how this interesting year is playing out in mid-July at our second quarter call. Enjoy the rest of your day.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010

componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc. First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over it to the Executive Vice President, Mr. Greg Larson.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome to the Host Hotels & Resorts First Quarter 2010 Earnings Call. Before we begin, I would like to remind everyone that many of the comments made today are considered to be forward-looking statements under Federal Securities laws. These st
componenttext:
Thank you. Welcome to the Host Hotels & Resorts First Quarter 2010 Earnings Call. Before we begin, I would like to remind everyone that many of the comments made today are considered to be forward-looking statements under Federal Securities laws. These statements are subject to numerous risks and uncertainties that could cause future results to differ from those expressed, and we are not obligated to publicly update or revise these forward-looking statements. Additionally, on today’s call we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial information such as FFO, adjusted EBITDA and comparable hotel results. You can find this information together with reconciliations to the most directly comparable GAAP information in today’s earnings press release, in our 8-K filed with the SEC and on our website at hosthotels.com. 
This morning, Ed Walter, our President and Chief Executive Officer, will provide a brief overview of our first quarter results and then we will describe the current operating environment as well as the company’s outlook for 2010. Larry Harvey, our Chief Financial Officer, will then provide greater detail on our first quarter results, including regional and market performance. Following their remarks, we will be available to respond to your questions. And now here is Ed.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. Good morning, everyone. After a challenging year in 2009, we are pleased to report that our first quarter operating results and trends were significantly better than we expected. As I will discuss in more detail, we experienced significant i
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. Good morning, everyone. After a challenging year in 2009, we are pleased to report that our first quarter operating results and trends were significantly better than we expected. As I will discuss in more detail, we experienced significant increases in transient demand and very encouraging trends on the group side of our business. While we still face challenges rebuilding our average rates, our recent operating results have turned positive on the top line and suggest that the industry is reaching an inflection point.
Turning to our results, first quarter RevPAR for our comparable hotel decreased by 2.3% driven by a decrease in average room rate of 8.7% which was offset by an increase in occupancy of 4.3% each quarter. For the quarter, our average rate was at $167 and our average occupancy was 65.5%. Our top line results improved on a relative basis each funds of the quarter and turned positive in March. As you may remember, due to the timing of our reporting period, our first quarter does not include the operating results for a significant portion of our portfolio for the month of March. Adjusting our results to reflect the inclusion of all of our assets for the calendar quarter would result in a RevPAR decline of only 1%. 
Food and beverage revenues at our comparable hotels decreased 3.7% for the quarter and total revenue fell by 3.9%. While our managers continue to strive to control costs, the combination of increased occupancy, continued pressure on average rates and a meaningful reduction in attrition and cancellation fees, resulted in a decrease in comparable hotel adjusted operating profit margin of 275 basis points for the quarter. First quarter adjusted EBITDA for Host was $126 million. FFO per diluted share for the quarter was $0.08, which included a reduction of $0.01 as a result of cost associated with the prepayment of debt and an accrual related to the potential San Antonio litigation loss. Overall, we are very pleased that our adjusted EBITDA and FFO per share diluted results materially exceeded our expectations.
Turning to our business mix for the quarter, the demand trends that developed over the second half of 2009 accelerated in the first quarter of 2010, positively impacting our business mix on a wider scale. For the third straight quarter, we experienced year-over-year growth in our Transient business with an overall increase in Transient room nights of more than 12%. More importantly, this increase in demand was led by our Special Corporate business where room nights increased more than 28%, and our Premium and Corporate segments where room nights increased for the first time in nine quarters at a rate of nearly 9%. 
Special Corporate demand growth was especially strong in our Luxury properties which experienced a demand increase in that segment of more than 50%. While average rates in both of these corporate segments were still down by roughly 8%, these are solid indicators of improvements in corporate travel, which is required for the industry to commence a true recovery. Overall, the positive shift in business mix in the Transient segment for the first time since the summer of 2008, held the decline in the overall average rates of 7.7%, which led to a Transient revenue increase of 3.6%. 
On the group side, frankly, we were pleasantly surprised by the pace of our short-term bookings during the quarter. At the beginning of the year, we faced a 4% shortfall in the first quarter, taking into account the record cancellations we experienced in the early months of 2009, and roughly a 6% shortfall for the entire year. At the end of the quarter, group demand improved by 0.5% for the quarter and our full year bookings are now trending ahead of the prior year's pace. 
Volume improvements for the quarter came primarily from a 14% increase in association room night and more than a 5% increase in discount business. While Corporate groups continue to be a challenge as demand decreased by 13% in the quarter, we saw a meaningful acceleration in corporate group activity as companies began to rebook business. Interestingly, our luxury corporate group room night actually increased more than 18% compared to the first quarter of last year, which suggest the  companies are feeling somewhat less concerned about the potential political ramifications of booking business at higher-end property. 
Overall, group room rates declined 9% and, combined with the increase in demand of 0.5%, resulted in a decrease in group revenues of 8.6%. The rebounding Group business compared to expectations and Association business in particular, helped our big box hotels as they slightly outperformed the rest of the portfolio. 
Looking at the second quarter and the remainder of the year, our visibility continues to be fairly limited because of the short booking window. RevPAR growth for period four exceeded 5%, continuing the recent trend of improving results. Group bookings continue to be strong as bookings in the first quarter for the second quarter have more than tripled when compared to last year and even slightly outpaced our 2007 level of activity. Transient bookings for the second quarter are also trending ahead of last year. Overall, improvement is still relying on the strength of the economy, but we are optimistic that businesses are beginning to loosen their travel budgets spurring a recovery in lodging demand.
On the investment front, as I discussed with you last quarter, the combination of structural complexity and secure-type transactions and little pressure on banks to resolve troubled loans situations has resulted in a limited number of assets actually coming to market. However, we are seeing investment opportunities in the form of distressed loans. Earlier this month, we purchased the junior tranches of a mortgage loan secured by a 1,900-room portfolio of hotels in Europe. The par value of the tranches we purchased are approximately EUR 64 million and we purchased the notes at a meaningful discount. While we cannot get into more specifics regarding this investment, the return we expect to generate on the notes meets or exceeds our return target for a levered investment. 
In terms of fee acquisition, as the operating environment stabilizes and begins to improve, our pipeline of potential transactions has increased both domestically and internationally and we are well positioned to take advantage of opportunities as they begin to arise. Our guidance continues to not reflect any benefits from property acquisitions even though we expect to complete at least some acquisitions during the second half of the year. 
During the first quarter, we sold the 370-room Sheraton Braintree hotel for $9 million. We also signed an agreement to sell the Ritz-Carlton in Dearborn. This asset is in one of the most challenging markets in the country, generates negative net operating income and has significant capital need. Since the transaction is not yet closed, we cannot provide any additional detail to the deal at this time. While we expect to market additional assets this year, we have not included any additional dispositions in our guidance.
Capital expenditures for the first quarter totaled approximately $50 million, which included $23 million of return on investment projects. During the first quarter, we completed the renovation of over 95,000 square feet of meeting space at the San Francisco Moscone Marriott Marquis, one of the pre-eminent group hotels in San Francisco. Subsequent to the end of the quarter, at our San Diego Marriott Hotel & Marina, we renovated the south tower rooms and during the quarter we completed the construction of a new health club. These projects are part of the first phase of what is ultimately projected to be $190 million reinvention of this hotel. 
In addition to the complete renovation of the rooms, this project will provide significant upgrades to the pool, food and beverage and entry experiences. We are also in the process of planning a new 40,000-square-foot exhibit hall and a 40,000-square-foot ballroom, which will have use of both the nearby marina and the downtown area. Construction on that phase of the project is expected to commence in March of 2011. We are also adding a new 15,000-square-foot ballroom and a 5,000-square-foot terrace to the Westin Kierland Resort & Spa in Phoenix as part of a broader meeting space renovation project. 
Given the strength of our balance sheet combined with currently low construction costs and the fact that occupancy levels are still below peak, we believe that the timing is ideal to accelerate the pace of some of our planned capital expenditure projects. As a result, we are increasing our expected capital expenditure estimate for the year to $300 million to $340 million, and we'll continue to evaluate other projects as we work through the year. 
Now let me spend some time on our outlook for 2010.  While we remain concerned that employment growth has lagged, consumer spending trends are still inconsistent and there are continuing risks to the financial system, it is clear that the broader economy is in recovery. Assuming that recovery continues, our better-than-expected first quarter results combined with the improvement in our near-term booking phase and positive results in April, have led us to a more positive outlook for the remainder of the year. As a result, we are increasing our estimates for RevPAR for the year to an increase of 1% to 4% with a comparable adjusted margin decline of 125 basis points to 50 basis points. Based on these assumptions, full year adjusted EBITDA would be approximately $750 million to $800 million and FFO per diluted share would be $0.58 to $0.65. 
In closing, we are certainly more optimistic than we were on our call last quarter. We are seeing signs of recovery in demand and we'll continue to work with our hotels and monitor our pricing strategy for improvement on the rate side. On the investment front, we know from experience that early-stage acquisitions tend to outperform so we will continue to aggressively look for investment opportunities both domestically and internationally. In addition, we will continue to develop reinvestment opportunities within our existing portfolio in order to take advantage of favorable costs and occupancy levels. We took significant steps last year to improve our balance sheet and we are well prepared for opportunities as they arise. Thank you, and let me turn the call over to Larry Harvey, our Chief Financial Officer.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ed. Let me start by giving you some detail on comparable hotel RevPAR results. Looking at the portfolio based on property types, our airport hotels performed the best during the quarter, with a RevPAR decline of 0.9% as the hotels benefited for
componenttext:
Thank you, Ed. Let me start by giving you some detail on comparable hotel RevPAR results. Looking at the portfolio based on property types, our airport hotels performed the best during the quarter, with a RevPAR decline of 0.9% as the hotels benefited for the poor weather in the Northeast that led to numerous flight cancellations and layovers. RevPAR for our urban hotels increased 1.7%, while RevPAR suburban and resort conference hotels fell 2.4% and 4.8%, respectively. Before I address individual market performance, I wanted to mention that half of our top 20 markets had positive RevPAR for the quarter. Our top-performing market was Philadelphia with a RevPAR increase of 12.3%. Strong Transient, Citywide and Group business contributed to and occupancy increase of nearly 9% and an ADR decline of 2.8%. For the second quarter, we expect the Philadelphia market to underperform the portfolio due to lower levels of both transient and group demand.
As expected, the Miami Fort Lauderdale market performed very well with a RevPAR increase of 10.3%. Occupancy was up 6.4% and the rate was up 1.7%. Yes, that's right. I said rate was up in the market. The outperformance was driven by growth in Transient and Group business generated by the Super Bowl and Pro Bowl, as well as the impact of the late 2009 ballroom addition at the Harbor Beach Marriott Resort & Spa. We expect the Miami Fort Lauderdale market to have a weaker second quarter but still have positive RevPAR. The San Antonio market also performed very well, with a RevPAR increase of 7.3%. A strong citywide calendar drove an increase in compression days leading to an increase in occupancy of 5.4% and limiting the rate decline to only 0.8%. We expect San Antonio to have a decent second quarter and a strong second half of the year. 
RevPAR for Boston increased 6.7% due to better transient and group demand. Occupancy was up 5.7% and ADR declined 5.1%. Some of the improvement was due to easier comparisons as the Boston Marriott Copley Place and Sheraton Boston were under renovation in the first quarter of 2009. We expect our Boston hotels to have a great second quarter with double-digit RevPAR growth due to strong citywide activity and improvement in transient demand. 
Orange County, a market that was extremely hard hit by the housing market meltdown, had RevPAR growth of 6.7% in the quarter. Transient demand across all segments showed signs of recovery. Occupancy was up 10.2% while ADR was down 7.9%. We expect the Orange County market to continue to perform well in the second quarter. 
We were also pleasantly surprised by the outperformance of New York City, where RevPAR increased 2.6% as occupancy grew by 7.7% and rate declined 7.7%. Business transient and shortening group bookings drove the improvement in demand. We expect New York City to have an outstanding second quarter due to high levels of business transient demand. 
RevPAR for our Chicago properties fell 11.2% due to significant decline in citywide activity which was partially offset by an increase in special corporate and discount business, albeit at a lower rate, as ADR fell 9.9%. The Swissotel, with its recent addition of 38,000 square feet of meeting space, substantially outperformed the market with a RevPAR decline of only 7.7%. We expect Chicago to perform much better in the second quarter and for the outperformance of the Swissotel to continue. 
Forward group demand and weak pricing across all segments affected RevPAR performance at both of our Hawaiian hotels resulting in a 14.1% decline in RevPAR, substantially all of which was due to a 13.5% drop in ADR. We expect the hotels to perform much better in the second quarter but we need to see further increases in airline capacity versus stay in recovery. 
RevPAR for our DC hotels declined 15.9% with a 2% decline in occupancy and a 13.4% drop in ADR. As expected, year-over-year comparisons for the market were difficult due to the 2009 presidential inauguration and related activity as well as record-breaking levels of snowfall in 2010, both of which were significantly affected Group and Transient business. Excluding DC from our concept for the first quarter, RevPAR would have only declined 0.6%. Our DC hotels had positive RevPAR in period three and we expect DC to have positive RevPAR in the second quarter. 
As expected, the San Diego market struggled due to a substantial decline in citywide demand and the absorption of the new Hilton that opened in 2009. RevPAR declined 16.9% with an occupancy decline of 3.5% and a 12.2% decline in ADR. A rooms renovation of the San Diego Marriott Hotel & Marina also negatively affected our performance. We expect the San Diego market to continue to struggle in the second quarter but improve in the second half of the year. 
For our European joint venture, RevPAR calculated in constant euros decreased 1.8% for the quarter. Occupancy increased 5.2% and ADR declined 10.7%. The Westin Europa and Regina in Venice, the Sheraton Skyline in London and the Sheraton Warsaw outperformed the rest of the portfolio. For the quarter, adjusted operating profit margins for our comparable hotels declined 275 basis points. This performance was better than expected due to the challenges created by four items. The first item was a substantial impact of cancellation and attrition fees. In the first quarter of 2009, cancellation and attrition fees were over $12 million higher than the first quarter of 2010 accounting for 110 basis points of the overall margin decline. 
The second item was due to our RevPAR decline driven by a combination of an increase in occupancy and a drop in rate, which is a challenge from an operating profit perspective. However, we were still able to reduce overall rooms cost for occupied rooms to improvement in productivity and reductions in several controllable cost areas. 
The third challenge was the loss of high profit banquet and audiovisual revenues which declined 7.3%. However, food and beverage flow-through was quite good as our managers continued to refine and implement efficiencies in their staffing models. 
The fourth item was the treatment of the ground lease payments in the New York Marriott Marquis. As we discussed last year, in the first quarter of 2009, $3 million of our rent payment was applied to fully fund the deferred purchase price of the land. In the first quarter of 2010, our entire payment was treated as ground rent expense, which reduced EBITDA by $3 million. We have the ability from today through 2017 to buy the fee interest in the land under the hotel from an incremental payment of $19.9 million. Overall, wages and benefits decreased 1.3% or 8.2% on a per occupied room basis, and unallocated cost declined by 2.7% for the quarter as hotels reduced management headcount and lowered other controllable costs. Utility costs also decreased 8.4% through a combination of lower usage, lower rates and the impact of energy saving capital improvements. For the quarter, real estate taxes were flat. 
Looking out through the rest of the year, we expect occupancy to increase further, which will likely lead to growth in wage and benefit cost at inflation after taking into consideration the benefit from productivity gains. We expect unallocated cost to increase at inflation except for utilities where rates will increase and occupancy improvements will drive higher utilization, and sales and marketing where higher revenues will increase cost. We will also incur cost for the implementation of new sales and marketing initiatives. We expect property insurance to increase at inflation and property taxes to rise in excess of inflation. As a result, we expect comparable hotel adjusted operating profit margins for the year to decrease 50 basis points at the high-end of the RevPAR range and decrease 125 basis points at the low end of the range. 
I previously mentioned the impact of cancellation and attrition fees on the first quarter of 2010 results. For all of 2010, cancellation and attrition fees will be significantly lower than 2009. Adjusting 2009 to a typical year of cancellations would result in an improvement of the above margin guidance of 70 basis points. With respect to our balance sheet, we finished the quarter with over $1.2 billion of cash and cash equivalents and a full $600 million of capacity on our line of credit. In the quarter, we redeemed the remaining $346 million of 7% Series M senior notes due in August 2012 and repaid $124 million mortgage on the Atlanta Marriott Marquis where the interest rate on the loan was set to increase 200 basis points to 9.4%. As a result of these repayments, we reduced our outstanding debt by $470 million to approximately $5.4 billion and we currently have 99 assets unencumbered by mortgage debt. Holders of our $325 million in Exchangeable Senior Debentures had the right to put the securities to us on April 15 of this year. None of the securities were put to us and the next put date for holders is April 15, 2014. 
This completes our prepared remarks. We are now interested in answering any questions you may have.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the fact that you’re seeing our business recover faster ultimately does mean that the dividend will recover more quickly, but we didn't have enough taxable income to support the dividend that we had talked about paying on the last call, the $0.0
componenttext: I think the fact that you’re seeing our business recover faster ultimately does mean that the dividend will recover more quickly, but we didn't have enough taxable income to support the dividend that we had talked about paying on the last call, the $0.01 a quarter. I think it’s always a little hard to tell where taxable income is going to come out, especially when you start to take asset sales into account. I don't want to envision that, even if we were at the high end of the guidance that we have provided, that we would necessarily need to increase the dividend because of the need to distribute taxable income.

componenttext: I have a question on New York. You gave the figure, the RevPAR growth figure, and it sounded like you were pleased but it seems like it was well below the market. And I only have general market stats, but are we seeing any kind of acceleration in the second quarter?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. In fact, New York, at least for our Marriott hotels, had a strong period four, so we're definitely seeing acceleration there. As I said in my comments, we expect a very strong second quarter overall, mainly due to really strong Corporate and Special
componenttext: Yes. In fact, New York, at least for our Marriott hotels, had a strong period four, so we're definitely seeing acceleration there. As I said in my comments, we expect a very strong second quarter overall, mainly due to really strong Corporate and Special Corporate Transient business. One of the things that I would point out that I know has been causing some, I guess just questions around our results this quarter, is to remind folks is that as I said in my comments, all of our non-Marriott hotels, so that is Starwood, Hyatt, Ritz-Carlton, Four Seasons, are all on a monthly reporting system. And for Host, just because of the way we time our quarters, we don't capture the March results for any of those monthly hotels in our numbers. New York, in my recollection in general from New York, is that it did better sequentially through the first quarter. We are missing the March results from both the W on Lexington Avenue as well as the big Sheraton near Times Square. So my guess is that if those results were added in -- I don't know that number off the top of my head, but my guess is if those results were added in, you’d see a little bit better performance in New York in the first quarter.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We certainly, David, at the point in time that the transaction closes will, as we have always done, give you some insight into what the price is. I would tell you that it is a relatively – in fact relatively is not the fair word, it’s a low price, but
componenttext: We certainly, David, at the point in time that the transaction closes will, as we have always done, give you some insight into what the price is. I would tell you that it is a relatively – in fact relatively is not the fair word, it’s a low price, but it is reflective of the fact that the asset, as I mentioned in my comment, is losing money this year. It lost money last year. I think it might have been right on the margin in 2008 in terms of whether it made or lost money. So unfortunately, we've been facing some big challenges in that market, not surprisingly, given the challenges that the auto industry has faced. We've postponed a fair amount of CapEx at that hotel because we've been trying to sort out the right resolution for it. While there is a and I think an effective way to invest a certain amount of capital dollars in the hotel, we've concluded that it would be better off being -- selling the hotel at this point than pursuing that path. So it’s going to be a pretty low number and with any luck the transaction closes in the next 60 days, then we will be happy to tell everybody about it.

componenttext: Okay, great. And on the European debt purchase, can you talk a little about what your strategy is, or what kind of return hurdles you're looking for? Is this loan to own? Are you hoping that it'll perform, that kind of thing?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I'd like to say, David, there, I want to be careful about what we say because we've agreed to certain confidentiality provisions in our acquisition agreement. But what I would tell you is, we would certainly expect if we're generally looking for r
componenttext: I guess I'd like to say, David, there, I want to be careful about what we say because we've agreed to certain confidentiality provisions in our acquisition agreement. But what I would tell you is, we would certainly expect if we're generally looking for returns, say in the plus or minus 10.5%, 11% range on an unleveraged acquisition, we adjust our return expectations when we pursue a leveraged opportunity. Where we've invested in this asset and given the underlying leverage compared to what we think the value is, we're comfortable that just as a debt investment, we will likely exceed those leverage return targets. The strategy for what happens with the investment will in part be based upon how the economy improves, obviously in Europe, and as it relates to these individual assets. We would be very comfortable if this just continues to be a performing loan and that we get paid off in due course, which based on the terms of the loan document, will generally come due no later than about two and a half years from where we are right now. On the other hand, we obviously are very comfortable being an investor in Europe and if the properties performance does not improve enough for us to be paid off, we would be comfortable being an owner.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I know you’ve answered part of this with Bill, but would you be comfortable owning hotels on balance sheet in Europe? Or if you end up in an ownership position for these hotels, would those more than likely go into the joint venture?
componenttext: I know you’ve answered part of this with Bill, but would you be comfortable owning hotels on balance sheet in Europe? Or if you end up in an ownership position for these hotels, would those more than likely go into the joint venture?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: I think in answer to that is more than likely wholly owned assets – or assets that we would be acquiring would ultimately end up in the European joint venture. We would be comfortable investing directly in Europe but I think, generally, we had found tha
componenttext: I think in answer to that is more than likely wholly owned assets – or assets that we would be acquiring would ultimately end up in the European joint venture. We would be comfortable investing directly in Europe but I think, generally, we had found that we like the joint venture structure that we have put together to operate over there. We've been very -- we're very comfortable with the perspective on investment of our partners and we'd like to see that relationship continue. So in general, I would expect that our European efforts will happen in the joint venture but there may be individual transactions that happen outside of that structure.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010

componenttext: Can you just comment a little bit on the single asset acquisition market and the portfolio market? And if in the single asset market, you think this is a better time to be a seller? And might there be more, I know you've done a couple, might there be more?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: The market is evolving on the asset acquisition side. I would break what we're seeing up. And again, as I mentioned in my comments, it's still not a flood of opportunities although our pipeline is clearly larger than it was 50, even 65, 70 days ago. I'd s
componenttext: The market is evolving on the asset acquisition side. I would break what we're seeing up. And again, as I mentioned in my comments, it's still not a flood of opportunities although our pipeline is clearly larger than it was 50, even 65, 70 days ago. I'd say that the opportunities are sort of splitting into two camps. There's one group of opportunities that are happening because pricing has been recovering, and I think you're seeing fairly low cap rates and fairly high EBITDA multiples, reflecting both the outlook for the future as well as the fact that we are at drop EBITDA levels. So with the recovery in pricing, you are seeing certain sellers who face debt maturities in the near-term who are thinking that perhaps it's worthwhile testing the market to see if there is an opportunity to sell an asset today, and at least recover some of their initial investment. I think there's another group of sellers, again it’s a relatively small group, but there's another group of sellers who are evaluating their business now, who are maybe more confident about investing in their own business but might be looking to liquidate certain of the assets that they have in order to then reuse those proceeds in a different direction within their individual business. I sort of describe that a little bit as a strategic seller because that type of a seller is really doing this because it’s a strategic aspect of their business as opposed to because they necessarily think that this is when they’re going to get the maximum price for an asset. I suspect that we will see more activity in both of these camps as we work our way through the year, but as you can tell by the volume of transaction activity that's been reported, in each instance the volume is still relatively light but we are relatively encouraged by at least the trend that we are seeing there and the number of conversations that we’re having.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: And portfolios?
componenttext: And portfolios?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: There's been more activity on the single asset side than on the portfolio side. We're fortunate with our scale that we can look at portfolio deals, but to date with the exception of some debt opportunities similar to the ones that we’ve moved forward wi
componenttext: There's been more activity on the single asset side than on the portfolio side. We're fortunate with our scale that we can look at portfolio deals, but to date with the exception of some debt opportunities similar to the ones that we’ve moved forward with in Europe, we really haven't seen a lot on the acquisition side debt to portfolio.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: We'll now take our next question from Joe Greff with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll now take our next question from Joe Greff with JPMorgan.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: With respect to your 2010 outlook, if you were to look at it on a quarterly basis, I know you don’t break out but just broadly, when do you see rate recovering to exhibit some year-over-year growth. And I guess, when would you see comparable operating p
componenttext: With respect to your 2010 outlook, if you were to look at it on a quarterly basis, I know you don’t break out but just broadly, when do you see rate recovering to exhibit some year-over-year growth. And I guess, when would you see comparable operating profit margins start to show in some year-over-year increases?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that’s probably the trickiest question that we’re trying to contemplate right now. What I would say to you, as you well know, is that the recovery in rates is going to happen on a market-by-market basis. And some of the markets that Larry talked
componenttext: Well, that’s probably the trickiest question that we’re trying to contemplate right now. What I would say to you, as you well know, is that the recovery in rates is going to happen on a market-by-market basis. And some of the markets that Larry talked about, that I think we've got a chance of seeing some rate growth relatively quickly, would include some of the big East Coast markets like Boston, New York and DC. I think New Orleans surprisingly is having a pretty good year and we would expect to see some rate growth there. Miami, in part because of the burst around the Super Bowl, but I also think in general we’re seeing some strength in that market. So that’s another market where we think it's likely that we’ll see some rate growth in the relatively near term. Portfolio-wide, I would at best say it’s -- it's probably at best the second half of the year. Certainly within the realm of the guidance that we provided, we're really not anticipating that it happens until the end of the year. And I think it's a little touch-and-go on whether or not we actually get the true rate growth for a full quarter by the end of the year. Probably at the high-end of our guidance, there's a shot at that. On the margin front, I think you -- our estimate is that we are looking at a 50 basis point decline tied to a 4% overall full year RevPAR growth rate. Again, my guess is that the margin and the -- because margin growth is going to be tied to both overall level of RevPAR increase as well as, to some degree, whether that is happening because of rate or because of occupancy, if there's an opportunity for positive margins it’s certainly near the end of the year.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-28-2010

componenttext: If you were to adjust your first quarter for reporting outside of, I guess NAREIT reporting system, what would have been a quarterized EBITDA number for your entire portfolio?
