headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just wonder when you're looking at your acquisitions, is there more sort of opportunity on the domestic side or the international side? I guess I've been a little surprised at the amount of international you're looking at. And on that, I think Marriott
componenttext: I just wonder when you're looking at your acquisitions, is there more sort of opportunity on the domestic side or the international side? I guess I've been a little surprised at the amount of international you're looking at. And on that, I think Marriott was the owner of the Rio Hotel. I'm just curious had you looked at that property before and things just came together to make it a purchase opportunity now versus in past years?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: With respect to the JW in Rio de Janeiro, we had looked at that asset over the last couple of years. There were some title challenges with that asset that needed to be resolved before Marriott could execute a sale transaction. And so once those were resol
componenttext: With respect to the JW in Rio de Janeiro, we had looked at that asset over the last couple of years. There were some title challenges with that asset that needed to be resolved before Marriott could execute a sale transaction. And so once those were resolved, it was possible for the two of us to negotiate. But it was something that we had been interested in really as far back as two years ago. I think it's somewhat coincident or opportunistic in terms of the timing that we've had that of the first four properties we've bought, two of them have been located outside the U.S. and two are located inside the U.S. I still suspect that on general, the majority of the acquisitions that we complete will be domestic. It's just that we have been active in these other markets, we've been looking in these other places for a while, we felt comfortable with the opportunities when they presented themselves, and so we acted on them. But by and large, I'd say our pipeline still has more assets that we're looking at that are domestic in nature than those that are international.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then can you just comment on, is the cost pressure, I guess, building for next year for the employees at the property level, I mean, do you have a sense of how much that needs to go up to next year?
componenttext: And then can you just comment on, is the cost pressure, I guess, building for next year for the employees at the property level, I mean, do you have a sense of how much that needs to go up to next year?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the operators are still sorting that issue out. But I don't believe that we're necessarily looking at anything that would be beyond what you would -- usually the employment cost index has a tendency to trend a half or so point above the CPI. I wou
componenttext: I think the operators are still sorting that issue out. But I don't believe that we're necessarily looking at anything that would be beyond what you would -- usually the employment cost index has a tendency to trend a half or so point above the CPI. I would suspect that as you look into 2011, you'll probably find that wage increases will trend slightly above inflation, kind of consistent with the long term average. We're not getting the sense that there's going to be any major movement to sort of, which I think is where your question is ultimately focused is, is there going to be a movement to try to catch up on some of the lower wage increases that might have happened over the last couple of years. And so far, we're not hearing that. And as we’ve talked a little bit, one of the things that might help offset some of those changes over the course of the year which Larry had talked about several times in his comments, we've had some pressure in the broad salary and wage area because of the bonus expense kind of coming back into our P&L as the properties perform much better than anticipated, and certainly much better than last year. We'll still have bonus expense for next year. But as you think about year-over-year changes, that bonus expense should not be as significant in the year-over-year context as it was in 2010.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: And next we'll hear from Ryan Meliker with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And next we'll hear from Ryan Meliker with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: First one, on your 2010 RevPAR guidance, and I guess the implied guidance for 4Q. It looks like it's at about a 5 ½% to 9% range for 4Q, coming in at 8.8% in 3Q. Is anything you're seeing that leads you to believe that RevPAR growth might moderate? Is it
componenttext: First one, on your 2010 RevPAR guidance, and I guess the implied guidance for 4Q. It looks like it's at about a 5 ½% to 9% range for 4Q, coming in at 8.8% in 3Q. Is anything you're seeing that leads you to believe that RevPAR growth might moderate? Is it the renovations you're working on? Is there something going on that would lead us to believe that things are getting worse in 4Q as opposed to getting better?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I wouldn't read into our number any sense that things are getting weaker. I think that the comp gets slightly more difficult in Q4. But I think that the one thing we did comment on, as Larry went through the different markets, is that we do have some
componenttext: No. I wouldn't read into our number any sense that things are getting weaker. I think that the comp gets slightly more difficult in Q4. But I think that the one thing we did comment on, as Larry went through the different markets, is that we do have some renovations happening at some of our larger hotels that are going to hit November and December of this year. Now the reason those renovations are targeted for that time of year is traditionally business demand levels are and volume levels are lower. So we hope that there will be less disruption. But in terms of thinking through what was going to likely happen in the quarter, we were thinking that we should at least provide for some room for conservatism in case the impact turned out to be greater than we expected. Now as we -- clearly, we've had a lot of questions in meetings and sort of, I think, there is in the industry about the potential impact of some of the slowing that we saw in the economy during the late spring and during the early summer and whether that's going to have any impact on our operations. And clearly that's something that we’ve been focused on. Now the short answer on that is that we continue to see very good demand. September, based on preliminary results, was up 9 ½%. September for us, meaning, September for our monthly hotels and period 10 for our Marriott International hotels. So that trend, that's favorable compared to where we are for the third quarter. Booking pace continues to follow the same pattern of being about in-line a quarter out and then getting very strong during that quarter preceding the actual quarter that happened, and then bookings in the quarter continue to be good. We're also comforted by the fact that as demand has continued to improve, we're finding more -- better and better ability to fullstop a limit providing discounts to customers to solicit business, and at the same time to begin to move rates. Of course, the broader economic or the broader fundamental in all of this is that supply is moderating consistently through the year and will be even lower as we work our way into next year. So the net of it is that it is something we've been watching carefully. We've been looking carefully at every monthly report we get to try to see if there is anything that’s suggesting that there’s weakness. And I think really what's happening, at least as it relates to our portfolio, which of course is very focused on urban markets and has always benefited a lot from corporate travel, is despite the fact that GDP growth has not been as strong as people might have hoped or certainly might have predicted early in the year, we're continuing to see that corporate investment and corporate profitability are very strong and frankly, are coming in better than where people thought in the beginning of the year and even better than where people thought at the beginning of the third quarter. We benefit from that trend, because whenever investment is up, corporate travel seems to be up. At least, that's what history suggests. And so I think that's why you're seeing the results that we're having. The good news for us as we look a little bit further forward is that the outlook for this point, for corporate investment for next year, is to be even stronger than what we're seeing this year.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then one other question on rooms operating margins. Obviously, you guys did a great job this quarter with an 80% flow-through on the rooms department. I think last quarter, you mentioned that typically, towards the peak of the disparity between the ra
componenttext: And then one other question on rooms operating margins. Obviously, you guys did a great job this quarter with an 80% flow-through on the rooms department. I think last quarter, you mentioned that typically, towards the peak of the disparity between the rate growth and occupancy growth, you get to plus or minus 80% flow-through, yet you were able to do that at only about 50% split between rate growth and occupancy growth. If I were going to assume maybe rate growth is up 80% of RevPAR growth in 2011, is it realistic to believe we could exceed that 80% flow-through or do you think 80% is still a peak that costs will start to go up a little bit more?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you could assume that certainly within individual quarters you could do better than the 80%. But 80%, a little bit more is probably in the context of a full year. I don't know that I'd be more aggressive than that.
componenttext: I think you could assume that certainly within individual quarters you could do better than the 80%. But 80%, a little bit more is probably in the context of a full year. I don't know that I'd be more aggressive than that.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: And next we'll hear from Jeff Donnelly with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And next we'll hear from Jeff Donnelly with Wells Fargo.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ed, if I can just build on Smedes' earlier question about the valuation proposition between domestic and foreign properties, just given the debate about that long-term health of the U.S. economy and what might be entailed to get us back on the upward tren
componenttext: Ed, if I can just build on Smedes' earlier question about the valuation proposition between domestic and foreign properties, just given the debate about that long-term health of the U.S. economy and what might be entailed to get us back on the upward trend, do you think you might be better served placing more dollars outside the U.S. in future years?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, that's a really good question, and it's one of the things that we have thought a lot about as we've gone through our different strategic planning exercises. Certainly, as you look around the world and focus on markets like Brazil, India, China, you
componenttext: Jeff, that's a really good question, and it's one of the things that we have thought a lot about as we've gone through our different strategic planning exercises. Certainly, as you look around the world and focus on markets like Brazil, India, China, you certainly see a lot better economic growth than what we're projecting to see in the U.S. And we know that economic growth ultimately translates into hotel demand growth. And that's really the most fundamental reason why we have felt it was important to explore opportunities internationally. Today, International, probably when you total up the amount of investments that we have in our portfolio in international markets, it's roughly in the 7% to 8%. That's counting in Europe just our share of the JV and not the total magnitude of the assets that are there. But as we look into the future, if we continue to feel that we can invest successfully in those markets, every country is a little bit different and every market is a little bit different. So as we continue to prove to ourselves that we can successfully invest outside of the U.S., I think for the very reason you suggest, that we would feel comfortable in having that percentage increase in an effort to try to give us broader exposure to markets that are going to grow better than what the U.S. is going to grow.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just looking here at the U.S., I'm curious how concerned are you that maybe some of the current prices that we see on transactions are being somewhat influenced by the low-rate environment that exists out there and that maybe a rising rate environment in
componenttext: Just looking here at the U.S., I'm curious how concerned are you that maybe some of the current prices that we see on transactions are being somewhat influenced by the low-rate environment that exists out there and that maybe a rising rate environment in future years, can you [audio gap] have for the appreciation potential because certainly most asset prices aren't off as much as the cash flows certainly would bear out?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think right now, I would feel comfortable that given the reduction in profitability that, at least, these markets that we're looking in experience, I would feel pretty comfortable that even if we ultimately come back to a rising-rate environment, frankl
componenttext: I think right now, I would feel comfortable that given the reduction in profitability that, at least, these markets that we're looking in experience, I would feel pretty comfortable that even if we ultimately come back to a rising-rate environment, frankly, I hope that we do because it would suggest a healthier economy. I would feel comfortable that the increases in EBITDA that we would expect to benefit from would certainly keep asset pricing well above where it is today. I mean at the end of the day, pricing should, in most markets, move much closer to replacement cost. And as I mentioned in our comments, we think we're buying at a meaningful discount to replacement cost. The increasing interest rate or the low levels of interest rates have had some effect, certainly, on the ability of people to pay some of the prices that they've paid. This is not quite as debt-driven an acquisition environment right now as what we saw in the '05, '06 and '07 time frame. Leverage plays a role in deals but it's not the driver behind deals right now because you just can't get leverage at the same levels that you could get before. So net of it is if -- you'll probably see cap rates go up over the next two or three years, but I think some of that is going to be reflective of, it'll be a little bit because rates are little bit higher, and it'll be because as we start to progress through the growth phase that we all expect to see in these assets in '11, '12, and '13 there's usually a little bit of moderation that comes as the anticipated growth rate moderates too.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: And since you brought it up, about replacement cost, show us what your thoughts are on the prospects for development. I don't mean just full service in the urban markets, but maybe more broadly in the industry. And I know that the conventional wisdom is d
componenttext: And since you brought it up, about replacement cost, show us what your thoughts are on the prospects for development. I don't mean just full service in the urban markets, but maybe more broadly in the industry. And I know that the conventional wisdom is development sort of off the table for an extended period of time, but the transaction pricing we're seeing in the market today on a per key basis is pretty close to where it was in 2004, 2005 when many folks are actually starting construction last cycle and I think if Marriott's correct on their 2011 outlook, the industry is going to be getting pretty close to being within striking distance, say, by 2012 of sort of peak revenues or nearing on peak profitability that we saw last time and construction costs are arguably lower. I'm curious, I mean, so I know it's not today but do you think in the next 12 months we could hear increasing signs of construction activity or do you think that that's still going to be off the table as we look forward?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Certainly from the standpoint of full-service development, I think I would be surprised if we saw real progress towards a lot of new development in the next 12 to 24 months. And I still tend to look towards the levels of supply growth that we saw in '03,
componenttext: Certainly from the standpoint of full-service development, I think I would be surprised if we saw real progress towards a lot of new development in the next 12 to 24 months. And I still tend to look towards the levels of supply growth that we saw in '03, '04, '05 and '06 as being indicative of what's likely to happen in at least '11, '12 and '13. When I compare the two periods, even assuming we have the same rate of recovery that we had last time, which I think is feasible, the reality is as we started a little bit lower so that the gap between value and replacement cost is certainly as great if not greater. The availability of financing in today's environment for new construction is weaker than what we experienced in the early part of the last decade. So while financing conditions are trending in the right direction, I don't see a lot of lenders racing to provide loans for new hotels and that will be necessary in order for construction to really increase. So I think you're right from the standpoint that values have recovered maybe a bit more quickly than people were projecting. The bulk of the reason behind that is that cash flows are recovering more quickly than people had projected. That will ultimately support new construction, but I think we've got a fair amount of time before that's going to happen. Now having said that, that's a full-service discussion. I think it's even tougher in the luxury market. Luxury sell more, and Luxury the last time was subsidized by a lot of condominium construction, where the hotel was an amenity to a condo project. That's only going to make sense in markets that have a vibrant condo market, and I don't see that happening in the near-term in most of the major markets across the country. We probably will see some limited-service construction sooner than we'll see full-service constructions. Those properties are smaller, they're easier to finance, the numbers have always tended to work sooner with that type of a product. And so I suspect that when we do start to see supply numbers begin to trend upward instead of continuing to trend downward, it will be because of additional supply at that segment.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one quick final question if I could. I know you haven't given 2011 guidance but as you think about that next year, what do you think will be the bigger driver of your RevPAR outlook? Is it just incremental demand overall, higher rates or more of a mi
componenttext: Just one quick final question if I could. I know you haven't given 2011 guidance but as you think about that next year, what do you think will be the bigger driver of your RevPAR outlook? Is it just incremental demand overall, higher rates or more of a mix shift just between existing rate categories?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010
componenttextpreview: Certainly, it will be all of the above. I mean, we are encouraged by the fact that one, the occupancy rebound this year has been as strong as it has been. But at the same time we're encouraged this last quarter by how strong the rate contribution was. We'
componenttext: Certainly, it will be all of the above. I mean, we are encouraged by the fact that one, the occupancy rebound this year has been as strong as it has been. But at the same time we're encouraged this last quarter by how strong the rate contribution was. We're probably -- if you look at how we've done, we're still not quite 50% back to -- if you look at the drop that we had from 73, 74 in occupancy in '07 down to 66 last year, we're working our way back, but we're probably at best about halfway back on that recovery. So I would still be expecting next year that we would continue to progress back towards our prior-peak occupancy level. But certainly, as you work your way through the year next year, rate will play an increasing role. And what's interesting is that as you look at what's happened to us this past quarter, is that change in business mix has been helpful but we've also been able to get absolute changes in rate within particular segment. And I don't see any reason why that trend won't continue into next year. So to sum that up, my guess is by the time we get to the end of next year, we probably would find that rate was a bigger contributor to RevPAR growth than occupancy, but both will contribute.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 13, 2010

componenttext: Great. Well, thank you for joining us on the call today. We appreciate the opportunity to discuss our third quarter results and our outlook with you. And we look forward to talking with you following the close of 2010, with more detailed insights into 2011. Have a good remainder of the week.
